data.title: Running Shoes Explained
data.meta_description: About a year ago, I took a job at a locally owned running store. Being an avid runner bordering on obsessive, the job was a perfect way for me to connect with the running community, do something I…
data.text:
About a year ago, I took a job at a locally owned running store. Being an avid runner bordering on obsessive, the job was a perfect way for me to connect with the running community, do something I love, and make a little money on the side.

One perk of working in such a specialty store is getting to learn all about running gear, and especially shoes. Another benefit is getting “seed” shoes from manufacturers to wear and test out so you can better educate customers on the product. In my time at the running store, I’ve received over a dozen pairs from several brands. It has allowed me to try different types and has given me a look into how each company builds its product.

There are many brands, with some of the most popular being Nike, Brooks, New Balance, ASICS, and Saucony. While each brand has its own unique look and feel, the parts of a running shoe across brands are basically the same.

There are many different features within each of the major parts of a shoe, and I’ll cover most of the main ones. The major parts include the upper, midsole, outsole, and drop. I will also briefly cover width, sizing, and the last.

Upper

The upper gives a shoe its “look.” While some are definitely more attractive than…
